definition: to keep someone in a place so that they cannot leave

definition: to draw pictures for a book, magazine, etc. or to put pictures, photographs, etc. in a book, magazine, etc.

definition: to believe that something is probably the case

definition: to stop something from happening for a short period

definition: to be interested in an event or activity and watch its progress

definition: to increase in amount or level

definition: to like a friend or a person in your family very much
dictionary_examples: I'm sure he loves his kids.

definition: to like someone very much and have romantic or sexual feelings for them

definition: If you need something, you must have it.

learner_examples: When you need help, everyone give[s] you help. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak)

definition: to have something permanently or for the whole of a period of time

learner_examples: I can't keep the sofa because [it] is too big. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

definition: to (cause to) stay in a particular place or condition
dictionary_examples: I wish you'd keep quiet. | I like to keep busy. | Keep left/right at the traffic lights. | It was difficult for us to keep warm, as the house had no heating. | He goes jogging twice a week to keep fit. | John keeps the car spotlessly clean. | The noise from their party kept me awake half the night.

definition: to arrive too late to get on a bus, train, aircraft, etc.

definition: to delay someone or prevent them from doing something

definition: to be familiar with or have experience and understanding of

learner_examples: I knew him in London, and when I knew him I was very happy. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

dictionary_examples: First, open the file called 'statistics'.

dictionary_examples: He remarked that she was looking thin. | She remarked on how attractive he was.

definition: to be a sign or symbol of something
dictionary_examples: The crosses on the map represent churches.
learner_examples: I think the sea represents life and the sacrifice[s] we [make]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

definition: to give someone a piece of information that is surprising or that was previously secret
dictionary_examples: He was jailed for revealing secrets to the Russians. |  It was revealed in this morning's papers that the couple intend to marry.

definition: to let the public have news or information about something
dictionary_examples: Police have not released the dead woman's name.  | The minister has released a statement explaining the reasons for his resignation.
learner_examples: The article made some valid points, such as the contradictory studies being released on a regular basis being the foundation of much confusion and that we should eat what we want, with a little commonsense of course,. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

definition: to make someone start thinking something

learner_examples: While a society is trying to plant the idea of 'living together', at the same time, the short-term resolution for this problem should be considered. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean)

definition: to give people information in a formal way

learner_examples: By presenting their findings to the public, they try to teach us how to behave in order to prevent this period of history from repeating itself. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese)

definition: to say something using particular words
dictionary_examples: I need to tell him I don't like it but I don't know how to put it.
learner_examples: Although I agree that there are awful program[me]s on, I think a total ban would be, how shall I put it, exag[g]erate[d]. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

definition: to officially speak or do something for someone else because they have asked you to
dictionary_examples: The union represents over 200 employees. | They chose a famous lawyer to represent them.

definition: to criticize someone for not being successful or not doing what is expected

definition: to persuade someone that an idea or plan is good

definition: to say that you will certainly do something or that something will certainly happen

definition: to say that you will not do or accept something
